title: What are the best graphic card HP Proliant dl380 G7? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ok I don’t know why Quora is asking me to answer this question 2 years later. For what it’s worth, the HP Proliant Series can indeed support graphics cards. You will need a PCI Express riser and a GPU power cable (on the G6 its a 10 pin connector on the motherboard that can supply either 1 or 2 6 or 8 pin GPU connectors). You may need to upgrade the power supply units also [potentially]. Almost any graphics card that doesn’t exceed 75 watts over the PCI Express bus should be fine (the rest can come from that connector mentioned earlier) and a maximum of 150W (for a total of 225 Watts). [Sources] PCI expansion slot definitions (DL380 G7) and DL380G7 and 150W graphics card support I cannot recommend a specific one but user benchmark at this time of writing has many G7’s with a graphics card installed. ProLiant DL380 G7 [User Benchmark]. A single slot height graphics card such as a GTX 1050 should work. You can indeed use a double slot card, but it’s a bit hacky and you may have to remove the rear shield on the graphics card to fit it. As for Jeff Rielley’s question/answer “Why do you need to put a graphics card in a server?” (who happens to work for Hewlett Packard). There are a number of reasons why you would install a graphics card in a “server”. It DOES NOT necessarily mean it’s doing graphics, but possibly extreme computation and/or AI. Rendering [as part of a farm] is also another option. Frankly coming from a representative of HP, shows a severe lack of vision. Even before the G7, HP had already considered the GPU within rack systems with its proprietary 10 pin connector.
